citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
Records reviewed show during post-surgical monitoring by Comparative Medicine (CM), it was noted that a surgeon
working on an IACUC approved protocol had not followed the IACUC approved sterilization technique for a pacemaker
implanted in a pig on October 31,2022. Records show the surgeon, on the day of the surgery, observed a deficiency in
the pacemaker they were planning to use. To avoid prolonged anesthesia and a second major operative procedure, he
replaced the faulty device with a fully functioning pacemaker that he had immersed for approximately 20 minutes in Cidex
disinfectant solution, which the IACUC noted was a protocol violation. According to the CSMC AV Guideline: Chemical
Sterilization for Reuse of Implanted Devices document, a guideline that is referred to in the approved protocol,” devices
will soak for a minimum of 10 hours in the chemical sterilant, rinsed thoroughly with sterile saline, and soaked for 10 hours
(up to 48 hours) in sterile saline. Devices are then ready for immediate implantation.” A review of documents and a
discussion with the attending veterinarian (AV) confirmed the approved protocol was not followed as written.
Documents show there have been 4 prior occasions when the same surgeon has deviated off protocol since 2018.
-On 3/8/2018 a bilateral femoral vein cutdown was performed on a pig without prior veterinary consultation from CM.
There were no complications associated with the procedure.
-On 12/21/2018 a pig underwent peripheral venous injection of autologous (pig) stem cells not described on the approved
IACUC protocol.
-On 2/13/2019 the PI scheduled a pig to undergo surgery for telemetry implantation as a stand-alone procedure. The
protocol includes more invasive procedures, so the pig underwent a less invasive procedure than what is described.
-On 1/27/22 an unapproved non-survival thoracotomy surgery was performed on one pig. Although a modification was
submitted 2 additional procedures were performed prior to IACUC approval of the modification.
The IACUC has determined there were no animal welfare concerns regarding these occurrences. Records show
corrective action has been implemented after each incident to prevent reoccurrence, but additional events have occurred.
Failure to follow an approved protocol may affect the health and well-being of the animals. These deviations from the
protocols were significant changes regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities that were not reviewed by
the IACUC. The IACUC must ensure that all significant changes regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing
activities are reviewed and approved prior to implementation.
To be corrected by close of business August 9,2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
